segments.text: subject when Abramowitz was turned down by the Malaysians the other day they refused him as ambassador down there this subject came up about somebody had said that he was and Carter he had been the instigator of Carter's withdrawal from Korea and the press was trying to just somebody trying to deny it but somebody doesn't know what the hell is going on all they got to go back and read
the testimony before the Senate Armed Services Committee when General Vesey and I testified for those troops staying there and Bromwich testified against it.
So, I know what the hell I'm talking about.
Okay.
You left Korea in 1976.
And then you had your last assignment.
Tell me about that special assistant to the CSA in which you did the Hollingsworth Report Central Europe Assessment.
That came about as a result of me developing a new strategy for the defense of Northeast Asia and Korea.
And it came about as a result of Senator Sam Nunn's interest in NATO Central Europe.
and as a result of his visits over there and the inadequacies that he could see as a senator.
So he asked the Secretary of the Army and the Secretary of Defense to, uh, I came back to retire and I went to Sam Houston, Fort Sam Houston.
Really?
Yes.
At this time you were, you were, you came back to retire?
To retire, yes.
Did you want to retire?
Oh, it didn't make any difference to me.
I got to where I couldn't hardly see out of it with one eye anyway.
And I was getting a little tired.
But no, you know, I never have retired.
I haven't retired yet.
But you really, you were not, you weren't interested.
I went on television by satellite for today's show and told them it had been decided that
by my government that I would retire and that's what I was going to do.
What told you about your retirement?
The Chief of Staff of the Army asked for my retirement.
Oh, he asked for it?
Oh, yeah.
You know, he didn't have any other assignment for me after I finished over there.
You see, three and four stars are
This is an interview with General Hill in Abilene and today is the 20th of August, 1982.
Let's start out, sir, by getting a little bit of background information for the record.
Could you tell us where and when you were born?
Well, I have a little clipping that'll, out of the 1967 Who's Who.
Okay, good.
that'll simplify that for you.
I'll go get that right now and hand it to you and put it in your file.
Oh, great.
Before we go on, I'd like to ask you if you would donate your information that will be on this tape to Texas A&M University.
Well, what are you going to do with it?
Copy write it?
No, we're going to put it in our archives and we're going to leave it there.
And we're going to give you a copy.
Okay.
Good, because we'd like to make sure that it's all donated to us.
Could you tell us a little bit about your parents?
Yes, my father was a staunch pillar of the Baptist Church in El Dorado, Texas, Schleicher County.
And I think he sold every windmill in that county.
And tons of barbed wire for fencing in the ranches that were going out of stock raising and taking a fling at farming.
That town is about 48 miles south of San Angelo.
On the old wagon road, it was 52 miles.
And it took the Model T Ford a long time to replace the wagons.
And we...

Actually the wagons weren't replaced until they got the hard surface road immediately after World War I. I think that stripped from San Angelo down to the Sonora and later, much later, on down to Del Rio.
That was a high dry country and they didn't know much about hard surface roads, but they decided to experiment out there where they had a good caliche base and dry weather.
And I think the first fifty miles of hard surface road was from San Angelo to El Dorado
And the engineer that bossed the thing and proposed the idea and got the estate to back it was the county engineer for Tom Green County, San Angelo.
So, that was when automobile traffic really came and truck traffic.
Sure.
fully displaced the animal-drawn vehicles.
Can you tell me something about your mother?
She was quite active in the Eastern Star, and she went to the Baptist church with my father, but oddly enough never joined the church.
sectarian branch of the Christian church that her father had belonged to.
So that was her one stand on independence.
Was your family pretty religious then?
Not particularly.
Not particularly?
It took ratheryeah, I'll stand on that statement, not particularly.
You said your father was a staunch Baptist?
Baptist.
But not particularly religious?
He was staunch and a leader in the church and donated, I think, more than a tenth.
He tithed.
But I don't know how much of it was good business among his customers and how much of it was greed for more guilt.
What was the authority in the household?
It was pretty well a joint command.
Oh, a joint command.
Yeah.
Very much so.
Now you've had a very successful career not only as a general officer but in the university world.
What credit do you give your parents for that?
Well, in the first place, my father was a
vast reader.
He had no degree.
I think he had what would be considered in his day a first-class prep school education and a private school down close to Houston.
And that education was provided pretty much
by one of his older brothers.
He got a good foundation.
He learned to read and read for fun.
And the novel was having its early impact on American history.
literature and even to the point that some of the churches were preaching against it as ungodly and whatnot.
But he went in for reading.
He read anything that he could get his whole hands on.
And he had the largest library, by the way, in El Dorado.
He had more books in his library than they had in the high school.
But that's not a big boast because the high school had its library largely consisted of an unabridged dictionary, a fairly recent set of the encyclopedia, and sundry books that teachers had
taken away from the students because they were reading the book instead of reading their lessons.
In other words, there were less than 50 or 60 books in the high school library, but our house, the front room, had a wall and bookcases, had a wall of books.
So you always read a lot then?
Yeah.
He was an avid reader.
And he had an old Chambers encyclopedia, an English edition.
I don't know where it came from, but if anything came up that he didn't quite understand,
He'd got down that 10-volume encyclopedia, I think it was dated about 1876.
And he'd look up the details and get himself on the track.
He was a remarkable man.
He was born in 1862 in the middle of the Civil War.
He had three brothers in the Confederate Army.
His father was a member of the legislature of Alabama through the four years of the war.
His father, I think, was elected to the secession convention that took him out of the Union.
I think he served, that was a convention, I think.
but he was in the legislature either as a lower house or the upper house.
Four years, I think he was two years in the lower house and two years in the upper house.
My father was born in 62 and had a very hard life.
His father was
a small business man in Jasper, Alabama.
And during Reconstruction in Alabama, he had to leave, and he left for New Orleans, for Louisiana, and he was also a lay preacher.
preach for nothing for country churches that had no pulpit, no regular, that might not have money enough to hire a permanent preacher.
But as a businessman in Jasper, he would go out and do that, and I think that's what got him in politics.
And he became head of an orphan's home
in Louisiana, held that job for a while, and he decided to turn to paid preaching as a way of life.
Well, pretty soon he had to leave Louisiana in the Reconstruction days, and he and his boys and family moved to Texas in the Houston area.
down around a little town named Grapeland, down in, I've never been in it, down around close to Houston, the city of Houston.
And that's where he got a pretty good education, was in that, in a private school down there.
He took a business college course on bookkeeping and spin Syrian handwriting and bookkeeping.
No typewriters in his day.
So that was from Tyler, Texas.
They gave him a diploma about the size of the wall there.
with a lot of script on him and so forth.
And that's the only thing I ever saw that evidence of education.
But he was an educated man.
Can you tell me something about your education?
Well, it's rather conventional.
One year at A&M,
Tell me a little bit about your primary and secondary education first before we get to A&M.
Well, the high school, the high schools in those days were making the transition from the conventional ten grades between the first grade and the
graduation and thethey were making the conventional When a guy had been through ten grades in a town of, let us say, two thousand, he was educated.
and he could then go usually quite often.
At that stage they did go to business colleges or they took longer courses.
Now the big cities at that period were experimenting with the eleventh grade or introducing the eleventh grade and advancing the
of knowledge to more difficult subjects, such as algebra, to quadratic equations.
When you got to quadratic equations, which was in the middle of the book, that was enough.
They could pick it up later.
But algebra was unheard of.
until I think they brought in the eleventh grade.
At least I never heard of it.
So did you finish the tenth grade and then start off at A&M?
Yeah.
A&M had a Why'd you decide to go to A&M?
Well, they put in athe city schools were putting city schools the size of, well, pounds
ten or twelve thousand working cities in those days, nineteen, ten, eleven, twelve, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, sixteen.
The big cities were already putting in the twelfth grade
But these smaller cities, like San Angelo, were saying, we want to experiment with the eleventh grade before we get into this stuff, because teachers of these advanced subjects were scarce.
Yeah, I would think so.
And incidentally, most of the mathematics teachers were getting, were being found in technical schools.
Most high schools had
two or three A&M students in it, usually teaching mathematics and very elementary science.
The teachers' colleges weren't in that business.
They were normal schools.
Particularly, it was reading, writing, arithmetic.
And as the tune went, talked to the tune of a head Chris Tick,
A&M was admitting people with a tenth grade diploma if he showed enough mental confidence to make a passing grade on a second class teacher's certificate.
Now in those days they had first class teacher certificates that you could teach any subject anywhere in the state.
An easier examination that I think stopped short of algebra or quadratics.
It was easier subject and so forth.
And anybody, it was pitched to entitle a person to get a job teaching anything under the grammar school level.
In other words, the ninth grade or eighth grade, something like that.
So you took that examination?
Texas A&M said anybody that could pass that second grade examination, a second class examination, would be admitted on probation.

I took the examination largely because the high school superintendent said that anybody that graduated had to show competence to teach past thehad to show enoughin other words, it was a comprehensive examination that he used and made it official by
having the certificate issued.
It was his qualifier.
So that was, I had the certificate.
And so I was admitted in the middle of the year.
I think I got down there in late February.
February of 1917 or 1916?
I think 1970, yeah, 1970.
And then that summer I got a job as a state driver and chain man on a survey team of the old railroad out of Fort Worth, Fort Worth and Denver.
I think the Burlington owns it now.

on the old Fort Worth and Denver and by that time World War II, World War I had erupted and the National Guard was already on the border or on the way home and those that were on the way home were immediately
It called active duty.
And everybody was volunteering here and volunteering there.
The entire senior class down there, I think, volunteered for the Officer Candidate School at Leon Springs.
The enrollment shrank from about 2,000 to the following year.
I don't think they had more than about the following
Fall, I think they had about, got down to the second semester, about 1,300.
And the upperclassmen were all, if a guy was over 21 years of age, he was going to an officer candidate school.
Well, I wasn't old enough to go to an officer candidate school.
So it looked like the campus, this is at the end of the first semester of 1917, 18.
It looked like the place was going to be deserted.
So I had a friend, to be frank about it,
I didn't forge my father's name to a telegram, but I managed to get a telegram anti-Britain on the stationery that the incoming messages were on.
It would pass muster.
Well, that telegram gave me permission to withdraw from college.
and enlist in the Navy.
And so that sprung me.
I guess the, I've forgotten the date of my enlistment, but it was about Christmas time in 1918.
Christmas time in 1917.
Christmas time 1917 is right, 1918 coming up.
I think that's, now of course in the Navy, the Navy took the Armistice Day for what it really was.
They said if the Army, if you won the war on the ground, okay.
You've made the Germans surrender all of their artillery and ammunition and go back to the armistice line and demobilize the army.
That's the great victory.
You've won the victory.
We in the Navy can't build ships fast enough if these bastards decide to renew the war on some technicality.
We will begin giving discharges to those who enlisted after the war began, after the declaration war.
He says we will begin demobilizing them as soon
As we know, the peace treaty is signed.
Well, the peace treaty wasn't signed until 1990.
Long about the middle of July.
The ship I was on was a destroyer.
I was a seaman signalman.
Where were you stationed?
I was on the Destroy Your Hearty, which is a thirty-knot, four-piper, crew of a hundred and twenty.
And we were, when the war ended, as I remember it, we were on the Azores patrol or something like that.
Did you see any action?
No.
No.
A distant whale with a good spouter could easily be mistaken for a submarine periscope.
Nobody had shot a gun lately.
No, we did a lot of patrolling.
I'll say this for those destroyers, you learn seamanship often.
You just don't, you either become a seaman or something happens to you.
Well, to make a long story short, when time came for
for Navy discharges, they put on the bulletin board those people who had enlisted in the Navy after a certain date and would be discharged, if they could provide an affidavit under oath from their
parents or former employer that they were either needed, had the job open farm back home, or if they were in college, they could be returned to their pursuit of knowledge.
So I thought I was in that second category.
So I sent my father a letter
told him that I could get out of the Navy if he sent me an affidavit that I had been both employed and a student.
And I could get out and go back to college or do something else.
probably something else.
I didn't add that, but that was my mental thinking.
And so my father sent me a telegram collect.
The destroyer was being overhauled and having her engines tightened up.
And the dry dock at the time
He sent me a telegram collect.
He says, you knew how to get my name on a piece of paper when you wanted in the Navy.
I hope you're equally resourceful now that you want out.
Good luck and best wishes.
So I went into a heddle with the yeoman that was the ship's rider.
What kind of, what was the best thing to do?
He says, well, it's very simple.
He says, if your college, he says, we're getting statements from deans and registrars of colleges authenticating the status of Tom, Dick, and Harry.
He said, we've already discharged two or three men on that.
And he says, if you were in college, get the name of somebody down there that can read and write and certify where you were and if you want a book, go back.
So at that time, the registrar at Texas A&M was a man with a fabulous memory.
the cadets all commented about his memory.
And his name, I can't think of it at the moment, but he became president of the A&M College of Kansas.
Now, whom would that be?
I don't know.
Which became Kansas State.
Yeah, they have an A&M up there.
It's a candid state at that town just north of Des Moines.
University town.
And it's in the same class as those, well, Lansing, Michigan is the A&M for Michigan.
Now this university over that I'm talking about is usually called by the name of the town that it's in.
Just like a lot of people refer to A&M as Bryan or College Station.
And so you wrote to the registrar?
I wrote to the registrar and told him to bail me out.
Bail you out?
And he graciously wrote a letter authenticating the fact that Seaman Signelman, first class J.D.
Hill, was a full-time student in that institution from so-and-so to so-and-so.
And that bailed him out, you see.
My father never mentioned it again.
That was a closed book.
Well, I guess that's enough about that.
What's the next thing you want to talk about?
Why'd you go to Baylor?
Didn't you come back to A&M?
No.
So you came back to Texas, and instead of going back to A&M, you went to Baylor.
Why?
Well, that's a legitimate question.
The truth about it is, I didn't want to go anywhere.
You really didn't want to go back?
I had learned navigation, I say navigation, but the fundamentals of navigation.
I knew I was a good seaman.
I knew that I could pass a third mate's license.
because it tells you exactly, before you take the examination, exactly what you've got to do.
I figured I could pass the third mate's license, but to stand for the examination, I would have to have another year at sea.
Well, that's the thing that I had just turned my back on.
One race I wanted out was I decided to sample the Merchant Marine and see what it was like to work on a civilian ship.
Frankly, I liked the Navy.
I thought I might like it better if I had more opportunity.
And I came back and this road building was in its infancy.
I'll mention that later.
So I came back and without any trouble at all, got a job in San Angelo on a team.
that had been organized by this fellow, I think his name was Gilchrist.
Something like that.
The engineer there.
Yeah, Gilchrist.
Was that it?
I think he was on the faculty at Texas A&M.
Yes, he was.
One time or another.
Well, for $150 a month, I would be instrument man on a...
one of his teams.
And most of it was just plain surveying and staking out and measuring off.
Not a hell of a lot of erudition was required.
And so $150 a month after
I think when I was discharged I was getting $46 and some odd cents a month.
$150 a month at that wage level, prices those days, was a good job.
And so my father was very insistent that I go to college.
And every time a college would open,
My mother would pat my trunk at the lease and say, no, not this week, not this week.
No, I wouldn't go there, I wouldn't go there.
So finally I stood them off until the end of October, nursing that $150 job.
The last college in the state that was still open for entering students was Baylor University.
My older brother had gone to Baylor, and I had a cousin and an uncle and an aunt in Waco.
largely through him, I decided rather to continue the family argument, I'd go to Baylor.
And my policy of Baylor was to take not the courses that I needed to know for any general special purpose, but to get a college diploma and satisfy the family
I was an educated person.
Well, in order to get out of there quick, you had to make good grains.
If you made good grains, they'd let you take one-fourth more hours than the regular schedule.
I think their rule was if you didn't fall below
you had A's and didn't fall below a B.
Otherwise you were back with the herd.
So my policy was, then I went back to see you in merchant ships in the summer.
And so the,
Hi there.
Good Scandinavian name.
Well, I was in Fort Worth.
I'll turn this on.
Well, today is August 21st, Saturday, 1982.
This is our second interview, and last time you told me that you did not like education.
That's the reason why you went to Baylor, because it was the last school that started the latest in the year.
And you continued education, though eventually got a master's degree.
and a Ph.D. degree, which is somewhat rare for someone who doesn't like education.
How do you explain that?
Well, there was another reason for not going to Texas A&M.
I guess two full classes had gone through there
during the approximately two years that I was in the Navy.
And so all of these fellows that I had known as freshmen were now sergeants and
cadet officers, those that were sophomores, were now the majors and the captains of the cadet corps.
And having been in the Navy for two years, I didn't intend to go back into a place where I would be at best
characterized as a sophomore.
Another thing I had kind of changed my ideas about engineering as a career.
And the most important thing is I made up my mind I wasn't going to go there because even though I could go there as a
non-member of the cadet corps, and to wear civilian clothes.
That was the trade-out with the returnees, many of whom had been captains and lieutenants in battle over in Europe.
So, I knew I could go there and
live a civilian life, but you can't live a civilian life on an army post because they have reveille every day in the morning.
And when reveille blows you have to get up the same as everybody else.
And when the noon meal is served in Speza Hall, you're there with the
